item.title: Spacetime is a quantum field with interesting fluctuations
item.description: arXiv:2406.09448v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Since Einstein's equations $G_{ik} = 8\pi \, G \, T_{ik} \, / c^4 $ relate the metric $g_{ik}$ of spacetime to the energy-momentum tensor $T_{ik}$ which is a quantum field, the metric $g_{ik}$ must be a quantum field. And since the metric $g_{ik}(x)$ is the dot product $g_{ik}(x) = \partial_i p^\alpha(x) \, \partial_k p_\alpha(x)$ of the derivatives of the points $p(x)$ of spacetime, spacetime itself must be a quantum field. Its points have average values $\langle p(x) \rangle$ that obey general relativity and fluctuations $q(x) = p(x) - \langle p(x) \rangle$ that when averaged turn Fourier exponentials $\exp(ikq)$ into gaussians $\exp(-\ell^2 \boldsymbol k^2)$. The gaussians make Feynman diagrams finite. Zero-point are also finite, but they are negative and too large to explain dark energy unless new bosonic fields are included.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Cahill

item.title: Tsallis-Cirto entropy of black hole and black hole atom
item.description: arXiv:2409.15362v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: The application of the non-extensive Tsallis-Cirto $\delta$-entropy with $\delta=2$ to the black hole suggests that the mass spectrum of the black hole is equidistant, $M=NM_0$. Here $N$ is an integer number and $M_0=\sqrt{2}m_{\rm P}$ is the mass quantum expressed via the reduced Planck mass $m_{\rm P}$. The Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of the black hole with mass $M=NM_0$ is $S_{\rm BH}(N)=N^2$.
